user.biography: National Geographic Explorer and NY Times photographer, creating an aerial perspective on climate change and global food supply @feedtheplanet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on September 12, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: A collective farm fills the bottom of Xico Crater, an agricultural reserve on the south edge of greater Mexico City.  Most of the sprawl in the Mexican capital has been from illegal settlements on former farm land and filling in the lakes that once surrounded the the Aztec capital. But the 100 acres inside Xico are an agriculture preserve, managed collectively by 120 owners, who guard their precious corn and bean fields from development.  Planting and harvesting here are still done by hand, without any chemical fertilizer or pesticides, resulting in corn yields similar to industrial scale farms in the U.S.. As seen two days ago.

location.name: valle de chalco estado de México

node.text: Jeep trails mark the minimalist plains of the Gran Desierto de Altar, Mexico. The creosote bushes are spaced according to their root structure, which spreads out just far enough to gather the water needed for survival in one of the driest parts of North America.  This area just south of Yuma averages about 3 inches of rain per year, with summers over 110°F.

node.text:
Maori activist @Tame_Iti had a traditional moko tattooed onto his face in 1995, the year before I took this picture.  Always a political innovator, he first gained notoriety by setting up a tent in front of the NZ Parliament building and declaring it the Maori Embassy, seeking decolonization and return of Maori lands. 

I spent many weeks with Tame, as his driver while he campaigned for parliament, which gave me a personal window into his world. 

If you have a moment, check out the Wikipedia page of an extraordinary trail-blazer.

node.text: Sam Querrey serving to Novak Djokovic in the third round of the 2014 US Open. Djokovic won the match in straight sets, but went on to be eliminated in the semifinals. This photo was taken in the last year before they put a retractable roof on the championship court.  From @NewYorkAirBook

node.text: Burning a sugarcane field before harvest in Costa Rica, 2021.  This is the traditional but controversial way of harvesting sugar cane, which concentrates the sugar and fertilizes the soil, with an obvious downside.

node.text: Yardangs are much more common on Mars that on earth, and are found only in the most extreme desert environments.  Caused by strong winds from a constant direction, they are usually found in dry lake basins where poorly consolidated muds are carved like soft wood hit under a sandblaster.  When I flew my paramotor in the Chinese Gobi for the first time in 2001, we had a hard time finding a jeep route out there, and camped under the stars to have calm morning conditions.  I returned five years later, after my photos were published in @natgeo, and the government had built a hotel for tourists, which was supplied by water trucks on a newly paved road.  The wind streets between the yardangs had all been fenced off, to prevent the delicate landscape from  damage by off-roaders.  I wondered if my explorations had caused a commodification of this unique wilderness.

node.text: Semi-nomadic Rendille people of Kenya live in circular villages on the arid northern plains.  The huts for people are on the outer ring and pens of thorn scrub for their goats and camels are inside for safety.  The Rendille are forced to venture far to find grazing for their flocks of goats and camels, and most of the women and children stay in this camp near the mission school, medical clinic, and water well.  Modern services are much needed, but the resulting population density strips the surrounding plains of vegetation.

node.text: It was still crazy hot and windy, but for the first hour of the morning the airflow was laminar enough for a quick flight below the escarpment of Lake Assal, Djibouti.  My paramotor shadow is visible at right. Take-offs are optional, landings mandatory.  #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Goat skull placed on the shore of Lake Assal, Djibouti, so that afternoon winds can coat it with salt spray, and create something to sell to the rare visitor. This is the lowest point in Africa, 500 ft. below sea level, and there are not many ways to eek out a living in this hyper-arid environment.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on September 02, 2021. May be an image of nature.
Photo by George Steinmetz on September 02, 2021. May be an image of nature and body of water.
Photo by George Steinmetz on September 01, 2021. May be an image of nature, ocean and beach.

node.text: Windy afternoon on the shore of Lake Assal, Djibouti, the lowest point in Africa, some 500 ft. below sea-level, with water saltier than the Dead Sea.  Every afternoon the shore is raked by strong winds as the heat of the Afar Depression draws cooler air from the sea inland, and the wind and sun combine to produce rapid evaporation.  The level of the lake appears to be dropping as there are old lake shore lines visible around the lake, like rings in a bathtub, approximately 200 ft. above the current lake level.

node.text: Oyster farming on the coastal mud flats of Tawian.  Access is at low tide with three-wheeled motor carts and cattle-powered wagons.  With a limited amount of arable land, this mountainous island has had to turn to the sea to provide protein for 24M people.

node.text: A village in the terraced landscape of Konso, Ethiopia, a UNESCO World Heritage site for agriculture. The metal roofs are reserved for homes, while the round thatch tukuls are for storing corn and millet, plus sheltering sheep, cattle, and chickens. The villagers bring their livestock food and water on foot to preserve the surrounding terraces for farming. Some 90% of Ethiopia's 110 million people are small scale agriculturalists, with few cash crops for income, or access to electricity and plumbing.
